msItem.rubric: Dominica i. aduentvs domini Secundum Marcum [1:1] Ex commentario venerabilis BEDȨ presbiteri
msItem.incipit: Conferendvm est hoc euangelii marci
msItem.author: BEDE
msItem.title: In Marci Euangelium expositio 1
msItem.note:
(CPL 1355), ed. D. Hurst, CC 120 (1960), 437/2–442/207.
The first in a sequence of homilies from patristic sources, not all originally sermons in form. The first sixty of these provide a series de tempore, running Advent–Maundy Thursday, with eight additional homilies de sanctis (four in one series), in the main feasts important at Reading Abbey. This summary report of the contents provides only manuscript foliation, the rubric giving the occasion and opening verse of the Gospel for the day (rarely quoted in full in the MS), the rubric identifying the author (silently omitting the frequent phrase ‘de eadem lectione’ when it occurs), and a brief incipit.

msItem.incipit: Quid sibi uoluit euangelista tot propria rerum
msItem.explicit: peccatum cui hoc meum qualecunque opusculum deuotissime destinaui
msItem.note: the linked series, BERNARD OF CLAIRVAUX, ‘Super Missus est homeliae 1–4 (divided as only three in the text), ed. PL 183:55–88. On fol. 246rb, within the third homily, a note in red, s. xii/xiii, by ‘Ingressus uero angelus ad eam . . .’ (PL 183:72): ‘Secunda die assumptionis in refectorio’.

msItem.rubric: In conceptione sancte mariȩ Secundum matheum [1:1] Scolia PASCHASII diaconi romanȩ ecclesiȩ
msItem.incipit: Cvr tali exorsus sit matheus principio
msItem.explicit: atque rerum omnium prouisorem fe credimus Qui nostra in carne per uirginem dignatus est apparere ihesus cristus dominus noster qui [form ending]
msItem.author: PASCHASIUS RADBERTUS
msItem.title: Expositio in Matthaeum 1
msItem.note: (Stegmüller, RB 6263 [4:171–2]), the incipit corresponding to PL 120:43. A marginal comment by the incipit (s. xiii) indicates that ‘Scolia hoc est excerptum’. About one-third of the final column is filled, the remainder of the page blank.
Added texts:

in addition to pen-trials, e.g. ‘Amen dico vobis’ twice, ‘Non plus sapere quam oportet’, and ‘misericordie’ a couple of times, includes four verses: ‘Clara dies pauli bona tempora denotat anni ’, Walther no. 2825, also cited from BL, MS Harley 200, fol. 147; and BodL, MS Bodley 487, fol. 7v.

supportDesc.extent: Fols. v (numbered fols. i, 1–4) + 264 (numbered fols. 5–268) + i (numbered fol. ii). 373 280
supportDesc.foliation: A medieval foliation (for openings), at the tops of versos, early, but not original. In this numeration, fols. 5–45 = I–XL; it continues, a little erratically, through fols. 47–230 in anglicana (s. xv) as xlij–CCxxiiij.
supportDesc.collation: 1–338. Added catchwords, s. xv ex., on the last versos of many quires near the gutter, usually plummet, although many in faded brown crayon or pencil; no signatures.
supportDesc.condition: Leading edges cut away on fols. 72, 78, 107, 218, and 267, as is much of the page foot on fol. 265.

layoutDesc.layout:
In double columns, each column
253 75–77 , with 18 mm between columns, in 32 lines to the column. Very occasional prickings; bounded and ruled in stylus.

handDesc.handNote: Written in caroline. Punctuation by medial point and punctus elevatus.

decoDesc.decoNote: Red headings in rustic capitals, introduced by a red, blue, or green arabesque initial, to set off Gospel readings and the heads of the homilies.

The Gospels are introduced by 4- and 5-line arabesque capitals (many larger I’s) in gold leaf with green, blue, and red, with abstract geometrical decorative designs; the homilies proper have 3-line arabesque capitals in green, blue, pink, or red, usually with some attenuated repetition of the same design.

Several drawings have been added in the margins: heads at fols. 90v–1; many faces (fols. 109, 130, 132v–3, 144v–5, 153, etc.); geometric designs in stylus (fols. 191–3v); the crucifixion (fol. 236 foot, in brown crayon); angels with pots (fol. 238); women (fol. 258).

binding.p: Slightly bevelled wooden boards, probably the remains of the medieval binding, re-covered with plain brown leather, s. xvi (?). Sewn on five thongs. Gold ‘11’ at head of spine; ‘11 Lib homil” in black and brown ink on the leading edges. Pastedowns marbled paper front and rear (the front with a College bookplate, inscribed ‘Cod. MS. XI’). At the front, a modern paper flyleaf and four medieval vellum ones; at the rear, a medieval vellum flyleaf, a raised pastedown from an earlier binding (ii).

history.provenance: On the basis of the flyleaf texts, assigned to Reading abbey by Ker, MLGB 158. This volume in fact appears in the book-list here (fol. 3) as item 15: ‘Alius liber omeliarum a dominica xxiiiima. post octauum Pentecostes usque in uigiliam Pasche ijo folio uerbum postmodum’. The editors of CBMLC associate it with one of two volumes of homilies entered together in the Reading book-list of c.1192 as item 143 (see CBMLC 4:443).
Pen-trials: ‘Robertus ?Grace’ (fol. 179, in faded drypoint); ‘samuel’ (twice, fol. 258, s. xv?).
history.acquisition: ‘Liber Collegii Sancti Ioannis Baptistae Oxon’ ex dono Magistri Ioannis Stonor de Northstoke in Comitatu Oxon’ Generosi’ (fol. 2, at the top).

source.bibl: Ralph Hanna, A descriptive catalogue of the western medieval manuscripts of St. John's College, Oxford (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2002)

availability.p: For enquiries relating to this manuscript please contact St John's College Library.

Nebbiai-Dalla Guarda, Donatella, ‘Les listes médiévales des lectures monastiques: Contribution à la connaissance des anciennes bibliothèques bénédictines’, Revue Bénédictine 96 (1986), 271–326.
Proctor, Francis, and Christophe Wordsworth (eds.), Breviarum ad usum insignis ecclesiae Sarum, 3 vols. (Cambridge, 1882–6).
Sharpe, Richard, J. P. Carley, and Rodney M. Thompson (eds.), English Benedictine Libraries, Corpus of British Medieval Library Catalogues 4 (1995).
Stegmüller, Friederich, Repertorium Biblicum Medii Aevi, 11 vols. (Madrid, 1950–80).
Walther, Hans, Initia carminum ac versuum Medii Aevi posterioris Latinorum, 2nd edn (Göttingen, 1969).

msItem.incipit: De ordine eorum que per anni circulum legenda sunt siue in ecclesia priuatim noctibus siue in Refectorio A kalendibus nouembris vsque ad Aduentum domini legitur dominicis diebus in ecclesia ezechiel
msItem.explicit: In vja. die legantur omelie euangeliorum Exijt edictum et Pastores
msItem.note: A list of readings for Reading Abbey (with the explicit, cf. items 13–16 above), ed. Coates, 84–5. Fols. 1v–2v are blank.

msItem.incipit: Hij libri continentur in Communi loco dormitorij semper parati pro lectore mense in Refectorio per totum Annum Biblia in iijbus voluminibus Prima pars ijo folio mouetur in terra
msItem.explicit: Iob in ijbus voluminibus Prima pars ijo folio Accepta Secunda pars ijo folio
msItem.note: A Reading book-list, ed. CBMLC 4:451–3 (list B 74); Coates, 84–6, with discussion at 66–7; and with discussion in the context of other early book-lists, Donatella Nebbiai-Dalla Guarda, ‘Les listes médiévales des lectures monastiques: Contribution à la connaissance des anciennes bibliothèques bénédictines’, Revue Bénédictine 96 (1986), 271–326 at 304–6. Fol. 3v is blank.

a contents table for the 73 [sic] homilies in the volume, giving the occasion and number of homilies for the day (sometimes inaccurately), the opening of the Gospel, and author. The last four entries, which cover eight separate sermons corresponding to our items 61–65, are characterized separately, again with reference to a programme of readings: ‘De festiuitatibus sanctorum que habent proprias omelias in Rectorio legend’ in hoc libro’.

supportDesc.support: Fols. 1–4 are on different quality vellum, 15–18 mm narrower than those of the volume and probably a four-leaf quire.

layoutDesc.layout: In long lines, 32 to the page. Prickings; bounded and ruled in black ink.

handDesc.handNote: Written in textura quadrata, s. xiv ex., a single hand for all three texts.

msItem.incipit: ihesus testimonium uocis huius sed qui per ordinem uniuersa
msItem.note: From a Breviary probably the service for the octave of Epiphany; cf. the later ed. BrevSar 1:ccclv–viii.

supportDesc.support: The second leaf of a bifolium, its excised stub showing before it.

layoutDesc.layout:
In double columns, each column
290 75–80 , with 20 mm between columns, in 36 lines to the column.

handDesc.handNote: Written in caroline, s. xii med. or xii3/4.

decoDesc.decoNote: At major divisions, 2- to 4-line blue, red, or green arabesque capitals; similar 1-line examples at smaller divisions.
Red musical staves for sequences on the verso.
The text is broken by 1-line capitals in the text ink.
